author: ralexstokes
content: We generally don‚Äôt want to fragment the base layer token as we migrate from eth1 to eth2; so this means validator liquidity is blocked on connecting the ‚ÄúbETH‚Äù pool to the ETH pool somehow. It‚Äôs become clear to me over conferences the past few weeks that ‚Äúearly‚Äù validators will want liquidity (many reasonable reasons for this) so we have to figure out how to bridge the assets somehow. While it may not immediately be obvious, enabling transfers on the beacon chain is akin to facilitating liquidity as I can transfer to unactivated validator slots which then serve as conduits for trade of ‚ÄúbETH‚Äù on secondary markets, etc.

author: ralexstokes
content: So the takeaway is that we need to sort some way of connecting ETH and ‚ÄúbETH‚Äù pools and this is where the relative timing of phase 2 vs the two-way bridge comes into play. I plan to start a feasibility study into the eth1 finality gadget (part of the bridge) so we can have a principled look at modifying the eth1 consensus; another route would be hurrying the migration of eth1 into eth2 but a lot of the research questions around EEs make this less likely to happen before we could build the two way bridge; note, though, that building the bridge makes everything more complicated wrt eth1 _and_ eth2 development so it‚Äôs not as simple as a round of client updates

Transfers enable a couple of things: first, transfer to non-active validators; second: rebalancing of funds between multiple validators (topping up one that went offline for a bit, for example). So although it shouldn't matter so much for people attempting to trade Ether it does have an operational benefit

author: jgm
content:
Although not technical, tax can have a significant impact on adoption of staking.

To give a simple example: if I have to pay 20% tax when "selling" my Ether to "buy" bETH then I'll have to swap 40 Ether for 32 bETH plus 8 Ether tax.  To regain my 8 Ether I just paid in tax I'd need to have a reward rate of ~5% for 5 years (assuming no costs of running my validator/perfect uptime/no tax on rewards) to get back to 40 bETH.  How many people are going to stake under those conditions, rather than hold on to their Ether?

If instead Ether is Ether, can be transferred regardless of if it is on main net or the beacon chain, and there is a two-way bridge between the two (planned or real) tax is longer payable on depositing to the staking contract (or at least it can be argued as such).

There are a number of headwinds against people deciding to stake in the beacon chain due to technical considerations (_e.g._ effective balance); too many and the technical merits of the solution will be irrelevant because the costs to use it will be too high.

author: alex.eth
content: While not perfect, regulators around the world have provided some clarity up to today.  More so than in 2015 when Ethereum launched.

author: alex.eth
content:
Won't put much more since I think jgm has good thoughts written above, but an example of an issue we could encounter.  Some people have talked about ETH having once been a security, but due to decentralization and timing is no longer a security.  CFTC head last week said he believes ETH is a commodity.  Also, yesterday he said he believes it's possible for a commodity to become a security.  We should be very careful assuming the methods Ethereum used in the past will lead to same results today and in the future.

Of course, I'm not a lawyer, but a devoted Ethereum community member since 2015.  I care a lot about Ethereum 2.0 and hope to become a validator, too.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**svantemand**
With the danger of this running off-topic: Ethereum is global, and no regulation nor tax is relevant to the base protocol. Asserting that Ether is either a payment, utility or security token is just as ridiculous as asserting that the Mona Lisa is either red, green or blue. It's all of the above and most shades in between. Regulatory bodies goes to extreme inconsistency of their internal logic to even try to make their claims make sense. Following a path to satisfy any regulation at base protocol level will end badly for Ethereum, even if we manage to do it.
